questions.question: Which of the following best explains Kartini’s familiarity with the ideas regarding social roles that she discusses in her letter?
questions.passage_header: Raden Adjeng Kartini, Javanese noblewoman in Dutch Indonesia, letter to a friend, Java, 1899
questions.passage: “I have longed to make the acquaintance of a ‘modern girl,’ that proud, independent girl who has all my sympathy! I do not belong to the Indian world, but to that of my sisters who are struggling forward in the distant West. If the laws of my land permitted it, I would be like the new woman in Europe; but age-long traditions that cannot be broken hold us back. Someday those traditions will loosen and let us go, but it may be three, four generations after us. Oh, you do not know what it is to love this young, new age with heart and soul, and yet to be bound hand and foot, chained by all the laws, customs, and conventions of one’s land. All our institutions are directly opposed to the progress for which I so long for the sake of our people. Day and night I wonder by what means our ancient traditions could be overcome. But it was not the voices alone which reached me from that distant, bright, new-born Europe, which made me long for a change in existing conditions for women. Even in my childhood, the word ‘emancipation’ enchanted my ears and awakened in me an ever-growing longing for freedom and independence—a longing to stand alone.”
answers: The expansion of public education systems as governments increasingly centralized
The spread of Enlightenment thought as empires consolidated control over their territories
The development of new mass media technologies such as radio
The increasing overseas migration of Asians as laborers in European colonies
questions.explanation: Kartini’s familiarity with the ideas regarding social roles that she discusses in her letter is best explained by the spread of Enlightenment thought as empires consolidated control over their territories. Kartini’s letter reflects her awareness of the ideas of the Enlightenment, which emphasized the importance of reason, individualism, and the rights of the individual. These ideas were spread through the European empires that controlled Indonesia, where Kartini lived. The Enlightenment ideas that Kartini was exposed to influenced her thinking about the

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the author’s approach in the first paragraph?
questions.passage_header: Joaquim Nabuco, Brazilian writer and political activist, Abolitionism, book published 1883
questions.passage: “We often see articles in our [Brazilian] newspapers trying to convince the reader that slavery among us is a very mild and pleasant condition for the slave—so often, in fact, that one may almost begin to believe that, if slaves were asked, they would prefer slavery to freedom. This only proves that newspaper articles are not written by slaves. . . .The legal position of slaves in Brazil can be summed up in these words: the Constitution does not apply to them. Our [1824] Constitution is full of lofty ideas [such as]: ‘No citizen can be forced to do anything except as required by law;’ ‘The law shall apply equally to every person;’ ‘Whipping, torture, and all other cruel punishments are abolished,’ etc. Yet, in this ostensibly free nation . . . we must have, on a daily basis, judges, police, and, if need be, the army and navy employed to force enslaved men, women, and children to work night and day without any compensation. To admit this in the highest law of the land would reduce the list of Brazilian freedoms to a transparent fraud. For this reason the Constitution does not even mention slaves or attempt to regulate their status.”
questions.explanation: The author’s approach in the first paragraph is best described as using sarcasm to highlight the weakness of the proslavery arguments. The author uses sarcasm to criticize the proslavery arguments that are often made in Brazilian newspapers. The author notes that these articles often try to convince readers
answers: Relying on statistical data to determine the true conditions of slavery
Illustrating the damage of slavery by quoting from written slave narratives
Using sarcasm to highlight the weakness of the proslavery arguments
Providing evidence to corroborate the newspapers’ position

questions.question: Which of the following claims does Edmund Burke not argue in our reading "Society is Indeed a Contract"?
questions.explanation: Edmund Burke does not argue there is a contract between men and their ancestors, but instead a contract between fellow men.
answers: Human beings have material, scientific, artistic, and moral needs.
Society is a contract between men, their ancestors, and God, in which the Christian God is society's ultimate guarantee
Because Original Sin is the source of mankind’s nature, society is not to blame for a person’s conduct.
The social contract can be broken at any time, depending on the will of the people
Society is a mutual agreement just like a commercialized company so everyone in society benefits, from the peasant to the king.
Political change should happen "naturally" over time, not designed by man and not implemented too rapidly

questions.question: Which of the following claims does Mary Wollstonecraft not argue in our reading "The Mind has no Gender"?
questions.explanation: Mary Wollstonecraft does not argue that women should be taught how they are physically different from men because her argument is relating to mental attributes and that men and women were equal on that standing.
answers: Men and Women should be given an equal education
Women should be treated with equal legal, social, and political rights
Women should be taught how they are physically different from men and how to respect them.
Men and women have fundamentally similar brains and minds.
All society would benefit if women were to be educated the same as men

questions.question: Which of the following claims does Adam Smith not argue in "A Man is an Animal that Makes Bargains"
questions.explanation: Adam Smith does not argue that the govt. should regulate the use of the assembly in order to avoid harms to the workers, but instead argues that the govt. should not regulate the market and that the market should be free.
answers: The govt. should regulate the use of the assembly in order to avoid harms to the workers
A completely free world market would lead to a perfectly free society
A free market society is not really based on competition; instead everyone is cooperating with others to achieve their own self interests
A free market society is really just the conflict between those who have money and those who do not.
A completely free market will allow everyone to be universally wealthy and be the same class status

questions.question: Which of the following claims does Karl Marx not argue in "History of Society is the History of Class Struggle"
questions.explanation: Karl Marx does not argue that history is a record of conflict between different races because he did not believe that their was a superior race.
answers: There are four major stages in human history: tribal system of common property, ancient communal system of ownership, the feudal system, and the capitalist system.
Your job/profession in capitalism can determine what your family eats, where they live, who they see as allies, and they see as enemies.
History is a record of conflict between different races where inferior races will give up their power easily to the superior race
The communist revolution will lead to the establishment of a classless society (a society without different classes)
After the communist revolution, people will enjoy genuine democracy and social ownership of wealth
The communist revolution will only happen once the great masses of people become property-less and are forced to sell their labor for wages.
